description: From late Middle English audacite, from Medieval Latin audacitas, from Latin audax (“bold”), from audeō (“I am bold, I dare”).

entries.meaning: Insolent boldness, especially when imprudent or unconventional.
examples: The brash private had the audacity to criticize the general.
Somebody never pays his loans, yet he has the audacity to ask the bank for money.

entries.meaning: Fearlessness, intrepidity or daring, especially with confident disregard for personal safety, conventional thought, or other restrictions.
